elements.text: The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro
Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What do Jovani and Alejandro see on their trip?
Read for enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses
Ask children to pick a certain number of “tomato” Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to harvest their Connecting Cubes in various orders by color.
How can we be a good friend to others?
How can you tell if the characters in this story are friends?
Pretend you and your friend are at a park. What will you do there?
How can you rearrange the number of cubes in that group? Is the total number still the same?
Can you write a story about an adventure you had with a friend?
What materials can you use to make two friends?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
What are two ways we can count the blocks you used? If we count from the bottom, are there the same number of blocks as when we count from the top?

The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro
Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro
Read closely to discuss how the main characters manage their emotions.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Ask children to create a cow using Pattern Blocks, and then count the blocks.
Invite children to correct your mistake as you count the blocks in a different order.
How can we be a good friend to others?
How does that character show they are a good friend?
Pretend you are going on an exciting trip. Show me how you feel!
Can you make two groups of four? What if you change the order? Are there still four?
Can you write about how you feel when you are with your friends?
Can you draw a person? How does the person feel? Can you change your picture to show a different emotion?
What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of
Can you build a tower with these blocks? What if you made a bus with them instead? Would you have the same number of blocks?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro
Use Circle Time to build math background, encourage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question,
How do Jovani and Alejandro use counting in their game?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review counting.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Count Two-Color Counter horses “behind the curtain” and ask children to match the number.
Guide children to understand that the number of horses in each set is the same.
How can we be a good friend to others?
How do you think that character feels? Why do you think she feels that way?
How can you be a good friend to others when you play in this area?
How can you make these two groups the same number?
Write about why your best friend is a good friend to you.
How can you draw the same number of trees and apples?
How can you tell what letter is at the beginning of the word
Why did you choose to build with those materials?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

attributes.alt:
A chart with the title Thank You, Friend, showing three images of friends together and an email.
Images include:
•   Two boys dressed in similar hero costumes. The caption reads: Good friends like to do things together.
•   Two children smiling together. The caption reads: Good friends share and take turns.
•   Two girls sitting at a desk playing with blocks. The caption reads: Good friends do nice things for each other.
•   The email reads:
To: rico at mail dot com.
Subject: Thank you!
Dear Rico, Thank you for being a good friend to me. I like when we play superheroes. I think it’s nice when you take turns with me on the swings. You are so good at doing puzzles! I like when we read books together. I’m glad we are friends. From, Alisha.

elements.text: The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro
Use Circle Time to reflect, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question,
How can we be a good friend to others?
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Independently writes to communicate his/her ideas for a variety of purposes.
Ask children to build a superhero using ten Connecting Cubes.
Count the cubes in each hero and guide children to understand that the number of cubes is the same regardless of counting order.
How can we be a good friend to others?
What do you think about that character?
Can you pretend to be the strongest superhero ever?
Can you put these groups in order from smallest to largest?
Write a story about a superhero who can count faster than anyone in the world!
What is your favorite part about what you have made?
What is the first letter of your name? Can you point to it?
Can you build a superhero? What material will you use first?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: crayons (Lucie Lang), pencils (urfin).
The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro
Use Circle Time to play a counting game and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How does having a friend make Jovani and Alejandro’s trip fun?
Read and reenact the story for physical engagement and imagination.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Write a number story about an activity you like do to with your friends.
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Imagine this character were real. Do you think she would be a good friend for you to have?
Imagine having a pet. How could you be a good friend to your pet?
I see three cows. Imagine if this cow stood over here instead. Would there still be three in all?
Write about the best friend in the world.
Can you create a poster about all of your favorite things to do with your friends?
Imagine you need a gift for a friend. What could you build for them?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Count 1–10 items with one count per item.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.

Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole/small-group writing activities.

Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/ feelings and behaviors.
